A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
The length l_A(M) of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers l such that there is a chain of submodules 0 subsetneq M_1 subsetneq M_2 subsetneq ... subsetneq M_l = M of length l.
Does the concept of a/an Free system of generators (basis) need to be defined for a definition of a/an Length of an A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the length of an A-module, as defined, involves the supremum of lengths of chains of submodules within the module. This definition focuses on the structure of submodules and does not inherently require the concept of a basis or a free system of generators. The length of an A-module is concerned with the hierarchical arrangement of submodules and their maximal chains, rather than the linear independence or generating properties of elements within the module.

On the other hand, a free system of generators (basis) is defined as a set of linearly independent elements that generate the module. This concept is crucial in understanding the structure of the module in terms of its generators and their linear independence, but it is not directly related to the concept of the length of a module, which is more about the submodule structure rather than the properties of specific elements or generators.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of the length of an A-module do not depend on the concept of a free system of generators. The length can be defined and analyzed without reference to whether the module has a basis or not.
